column3: Q1. Which of the following best describe(s) in English how you think of yourself?
column4: Q2. Tell us about any words or phrases not listed above that best describe in English how you think of yourself, in any order.
column5: Q3. When someone writes "Dear [your name]" at the top of an addressed letter/email, what title would you want someone to use when writing to you, if any?
column6: Q4. In the previous question, you chose "a title not listed here". What is your preferred title?
column7: Q5. Is this title usually associated with a particular gender?
column8: Q7. When a stranger addresses you and they don't know your name, what title(s) would you want someone to use, if any?
column9: Q8. Tell us about any titles not listed above that you want people to use for you, in any order.Please DO NOT type anything other than your title(s). (No definitions, explanations, unabbreviations or pronunciation guides, please.)
column10: Q9. Supposing all pronouns were accepted by everyone without question and were easy to learn, which pronouns are you happy for people to use for you in English?
column11: Q9. If there are any particular rules that you want people to observe when using your pronouns, please tell us about them here.You can leave this blank if there are none.
column13: Q11. If your pronoun set is ever referred to with a name, what is it?
column14: Q12. Do you see this pronoun set as gender-inclusive (it can be claimed by people with any or no gender identity), or gender-exclusive (it is intended to express a particular gender or set of genders, in the same way that, e.g. he/him is generally considered a masculine pronoun)?
column17: Q16. If your pronoun set is ever referred to with a name, what is it?(For example, the pronoun set e/em/eir/eirs/emself is referred to with the name "Spivak".)If you don't know of a name for the set, or you only refer to it with the first two forms and a forward slash (eg: e/em), you can leave this blank.

column77: Q10.1. "Ask Sam if _____ would like to buy a newspaper." (eg: he, she, they)
column78: Q10.2. "Sam bought the newspaper, so now it belongs to _____." (eg: him, her, them)
column79: Q10.3. "Sam is reading _____ newspaper." (eg: his, her, their)
column80: Q10.4. "Whose newspaper is it?" "It belongs to Sam, so it's _____." (eg: his, hers, theirs)
column81: Q10.5. "Sam bought it for _____." (eg: himself, herself)
